posts.name: Oded Benjamini
posts.cooked:
Sure! Here's the cleaned-up version:

Hey there,  
We want to revive some of our older bots but don’t have enough RIOS to get started.  
I was wondering if it’s possible to run a full bot using a controller like Arduino or a processor like a Raspberry Pi. How would communication with CTRE's Power Distribution Panel (PDP) work in such a setup? If it’s not feasible to use the PDP with this configuration, could you suggest an alternative?  

For context, the bot uses 7 CIM motors and some encoders, nothing else.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: I'd target an ESP32 instead of the AVR Arduinos (faster and built-in wireless communications). Then explore suitable motor controllers and power them with PWM signals instead of CAN. With the Rio phased out next year, I don't blame you for not wanting to purchase another, but consider getting one second-hand.

posts.name: Pedro Braga
posts.cooked: Do you really need PDP communication? That’s probably more work than it’s worth. All it gives you is current monitoring, and you probably don’t need that on all the channels. It might be best to just put current sensors where they’re needed.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked: You can use a Raspberry Pi or Jetson Nano with CTRE (Cross The Road Electronics) devices. This includes Talon SRX, Victor SPX, Pigeon 1.0, Original PDP (CTRE's Power Distribution Panel), and the Gadgeteer based sensors. These devices will work with a Canable or Hero Board equipped with custom firmware as the adapter.

Using a Raspberry Pi as a RoboRIO Replacement – Any Resources or Examples?

posts.name: Oded Benjamini
posts.cooked: My main concern with CTRE's Power Distribution Panel (PDP) was its ability to properly supply power to all components. Is there an alternative method that doesn’t involve using the PDP?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: You have been given a PDP[CTRE's Power Distribution Panel] to analyze its power distribution panel. This device is used for monitoring and controlling the power distribution within an electrical system. By measuring the continuity from the input to the outputs, you can determine if each component is functioning properly. If there are any open circuits or short circuits, this will affect the overall performance of the system. Remember to take measurements carefully to ensure accurate results.

WILIB installed on the Rio offers several safety features that must be replicated if using a different controller. Specifically, when the Rio loses network communication with the drive station, all motor outputs are immediately disabled. This is essential, as it prevents robots weighing over 150 pounds from uncontrollably moving within the shop or dangerous situations during public events, where spectators could be injured. A safer option might be to opt for an older Rio 1.0 controller.
